Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: High performance magnetic labels for more accurate quantification of biomolecules in complex samples
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of the Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to make more medical tests available at distributed testing facilities like clinics and pharmacies at a lower cost. To accomplish this, this project seeks to develop labels for biomolecules and cells which can be accurately quantified in complex environments which will benefit several types of diagnostic tests. lateral flow assays, for example, possess many desirable traits including fast results, a long shelf life, minimal training, and low cost, but lack sufficient sensitivity for some applications because the tags are embedded in a dense paper-like material that distorts optical and electronic signals. Magnetic detection, in contrast, is insensitive to biological materials and the plastics. This project seeks to develop magnetic tags which are more than an order of magnitude easier to detect with magnetic sensors. The objective is to create a precise and sensitive system for detection which operates equally well in any media or sample conditions. The feasibility of the product will be demonstrated by fabricating these magnetic labels and implementing them in existing tests and demonstrating more than an order of magnitude improved sensitivity as compared to existing labels.

The proposed project seeks to improve quantification of biomolecules in complex samples by providing a line of magnetic labels which are more than an order of magnitude easier to detect with magnetic sensors. Optical and electronic labels are both sensitive methods for detection but can be limited by the sample media. Optical detection is affected by scattering, autofluorescence, and sample geometry. Electronic detection is sensitive to sample pH and ionic strength. Magnetic detection is insensitive to the media, biological samples, and even the container. This is particularly relevant to lateral flow assays, the most common point-of-care test, where labels are buried in a paper-like material. Physics simulations have been used to identify a class of magnetic labels which should be more than an order of magnitude easier to count with magnetic sensors but will require new manufacturing processes. Work on this project will involve developing new tooling to manufacture this tag, measuring the magnetic properties of the produced label and comparing to theory, and working with medical device manufacturers to test this label in existing devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The national science foundation award 1519520 succeeded in demonstrating a new manufacturing method which is capable producing unique magnetic materials with properties important for telecommunications and biotechnology.

The first material demonstrated was an amorphous magnetic ferrofluid with superior soft magnetic properties which are useful for magnetic sensing and using particles as a magnetic labels for detection of pathogens. Although this material attained its goals, the initially proposed application likely will not generate sufficient revenue to warrant additional investment. The material is therefore being investigated for other applications in telecommunications.

The second material demonstrated was a carbon coated magnetic bead which has shown promise in separating genetic material from biological samples, which is an important step in medical testing. This new material was demonstrated to have the unique property of being able to separate double stranded nucleic acids from single stranded nucleic acids. Leveraging this unique property will make it cheaper and easier to detect a range of diseases.

The primary figure is an image of this magnetic material on the atomic scale. The cartoon included describes how this magnetic material can be used to isolate RNA from a mixture. The final image is this magnetic material being isolated with a magnet.

The carbon coated material was sent to six companies and professors at the end of the Phase I program for review and testing and feedback was overwhelmingly positive.

In addition to preparing new materials, the manufacturing method is extreamly clean and efficient and produces a fraction of the waste of other methods.

The next step for Life Magnetics, Inc. is to scale production, refine the manufacturing process, and develop protocols for the use of this new magnetic material. The company has attracted investors and outside capital as a result of the Phase I results and hopes to create at least 10 new positions by the end of 2018 in machine maintenance, automation, and life science.
